item.title: Highguard Breaks Radio Silence And The Internet Reacts
item.content:encoded:
40+ days after it was first revealed as the ‚Äúlast big thing‚Äù at The Game Awards in December, Highguard‚Äôs social media account finally posted again, breaking a long radio silence and leading to a lot of reactions from gamers online.

On January 23, the official Highguard Twitter account announced a ‚ÄúLaunch Showcase‚Äù live stream happening on the game‚Äôs release date of January 26. This is the first time the account has posted anything since replying to someone‚Äôs reaction to the initial reveal trailer back on December 12.

‚ÄúTune in on Monday, January 26, at 10am PT for the Highguard Launch Showcase,‚Äù posted the Highguard account. ‚ÄúHere, we‚Äôll share an in-depth look at Highguard direct from the studio, featuring a full gameplay deep dive, year one plans, and much more.‚Äù

Tune in on Monday, January 26, at 10am PT for the Highguard Launch Showcase‚öîÔ∏è

Here, we'll share an in-depth look at Highguard direct from the studio, featuring a full gameplay deep dive, year one plans, and much more.

üëâhttps://t.co/zm4I62mMpI pic.twitter.com/VlQ4qbCNA3

‚Äî Highguard | Launching Jan 26 2026 (@PlayHighguard) January 23, 2026

What‚Äôs going on with Highguard?

Since its reveal in December, Highguard has a strange few weeks. Being the big reveal at the end of the Game Awards, which reportedly the company didn‚Äôt pay for, got it a lot of eyeballs, but also a lot of scrutiny. People tend to expect some big new sequel or long-awaited project to cap off host Geoff Keighley‚Äôs annual award and trailer showcase. Instead, Geoff showcased a free-to-play online shooter that, too many online, looked too similar to many other games already out there. That initial trailer didn‚Äôt do a great job explaining what it is, and people weren‚Äôt excited.

Since then, the people behind Highguard have been radio silent, which has led to more discourse around its radio silence and discussion over what little we‚Äôve seen so far. So this new tweet from the main account caught a lot of people‚Äôs attention

‚ÄúBro finally remembered the password,‚Äù posted popular Fortnite leaker Shiina.

‚ÄúI logged in specifically just to mute you,‚Äù said another user on Twitter.

‚ÄúOh my word, they are alive,‚Äù posted someone else.

‚ÄúDead game,‚Äù tweeted another user, because of course, at least one person had to shout this overused moniker.

To be clear, there are some positive replies, too. People are excited to see what the game actually is, or people are just happy the devs aren‚Äôt giving up on it. Regardless of sentiment, Highguard clearly has the attention of a lot of people online, even if some of them are rooting for it to fail while others are just curious as to how this all ends. We won‚Äôt have to wait long to see more as Highguard‚Äôs big launch day stream kicks off on January 26. Meanwhile, the game launches that day on consoles and PC. I suspect a lot of eyeballs will once again be watching.

item.title: Made That Controller For You Boss, Added A Heartbeat Sensor And Built-In Screen Just Like You Asked
item.content:encoded:
Anbernic, a hardware company primarily known for its retro gaming handhelds, is hopping into the world of high-end gamepads with a strange, but oddly intriguing, controller that contains a heartbeat sensor.

As spotted by our sister site Gizmodo, the Anbernic RG GO1 is a newly announced wireless controller designed to work with PC, mobile phones, and the Nintendo Switch. And it‚Äôs an odd duck. The RG GO1, which doesn‚Äôt have a price or specific release date yet, features a 2.5-inch IPS LCD screen in the center of the controller. This can be used for various tasks, including reprogramming buttons and turning on rapid fire settings. The just-revealed controller also includes heartbeat sensors in the grips. Why? Anbernic says it will let you ‚Äúmonitor your well-being during intense sessions.‚Äù Sure!

Other features included are back buttons, six-axis gyro control, rumble motors for vibration, dual-mode triggers, Bluetooth support, and Purple Kirin‚Äôs electro-inductive capacitive joysticks, which the company claims will provide ‚Äúsilky-smooth movement.‚Äù Plus, the RG GO1‚Äôs face is clear plastic, letting you see some of the innards of the controller, and I‚Äôm a sucker for that.

The RG GO1 is ‚Äúcoming soon.‚Äù We don‚Äôt have a price, but it will likely be more expensive than the company‚Äôs other controller, the $18 RG P01. But can you put a price on weird and cool? I‚Äôm being told, yes. Yes, you can.

item.title: It‚Äôs Not Too Late To Save Beloved Gaming Franchises That Have Become Too Big To Fail
item.content:encoded:
Dead Space was revealed to be permanently on ice last year. We haven‚Äôt seen a non-VR version of the Thief franchise since 2014. Deus Ex has lain dormant for a decade. Titanfall 2 also came out ten years ago. There hasn‚Äôt been a new 3D Prince of Persia for 16 years, and with this week‚Äôs news it‚Äôs looking unlikely to return. So many massive, deeply loved gaming franchises are routinely being shelved by companies too afraid to gamble the nine-figure sums publishers believe is necessary for success. Yet there‚Äôs such an obvious solution! 

Every time I read a headline about a game franchise being shelved because it‚Äôs become too expensive, too big of a risk for a publisher to gamble $200 million on, I want to scream into the sky at the obviousness of the solution. But now, following the 2025 success of games like Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, Arc Raiders, Lies of P, and Helldivers 2, surely the answer is clear to everyone? License these once big-name franchises to proven mid-size AA teams, and don‚Äôt interfere.

In the wake of Ubisoft‚Äôs latest disastrous plan to rearrange itself by cancelling multiple projects, and the seemingly constant drip of major publishers shelving major franchises, all while giant company buys giant company for imaginary money, the industry has clearly got itself into a very bad place. Right now, during this grotesque phase of consolidation, with multi-billion-dollar sales seeing publishers consume one another, a financial black hole is being formed.

With the colossally over-inflated prices involved in these deals, those buying are either borrowing heavily from predatory investors or gambling huge stakes of their own fortunes, such that the sheer notion of creating a new game in a once-loved series (let alone an original IP) becomes fantastically risky. To match the ridiculous valuations, the games these companies make are burdened with a need for justification, and every project must be predicted to bring in at least half a billion bucks to be worth even storyboarding. Ubisoft has just declared that it intends the games it makes to annually bring in a billion dollars each! Development costs therefore become self-destructively high, with expectations of figures of at least $200 million being spent to create something with enough spectacle to dazzle a hypothetical mainstream audience. Everything now needs to be the next Call of Duty at a time when even Call of Duty can‚Äôt manage that.

Sure, welcome to capitalism 101: It doesn‚Äôt work. The need to always grow bigger, for share values to always increase, is a model so unsustainable that a pre-schooler could explain why. But here‚Äôs the thing, also easily grasped by toddlers: a moderately successful game that costs around $50 million to develop will make an awful lot more money than no game at all.

Dead Space Needn‚Äôt Be Dead

The most recent example of a beloved game series being shelved is Dead Space. In late 2025, following rumors some months before that a Dead Space 2 remake had been cancelled after the supposedly disappointing sales for 2023‚Äôs remake of the original game, word went around that EA had put the franchise ‚Äúon ice.‚Äù In December 2024 we‚Äôd also learned that the series‚Äô original creators had tried to pitch a Dead Space 4 to EA, but had been immediately rejected. One of those original creators, Glen Schofield, still didn‚Äôt give up, maintaining in October last year that he was attempting to buy the IP back from EA in the wake of the company‚Äôs attempted sale to Saudi Arabia, but by December 2025 this looked incredibly unlikely. Which is crazy! Because a new Dead Space is not something EA needs to be the least bit afraid of.

The original Dead Space, released in 2008, cost approximately $37 million to make. Adjusted for inflation, that‚Äôs $55 million in 2026 money. And that was an in-house Electronic Arts studio, spending EA money within EA‚Äôs ludicrous corporate structure. I truly believe, with my whole lovely heart, that a well-established AA team would be easily capable of making a game of the caliber of that first, excellent horror-shooter for even less money than that, especially if innovative and novel ideas are used in place of the very fanciest modern graphics.

Here‚Äôs another thing my heart believes: That Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time remake that Ubisoft was unable to make for six agonizing years before eventually killing it entirely, could have been turned around by any number of excellent smaller teams. I‚Äôm not suggesting for a moment it would be easy to do so‚Äîit would be fantastically hard, just like making any other top-quality game‚Äîbut it would be eminently achievable. Not least because, not being made internally at Ubisoft, it wouldn‚Äôt have Ubisoft constantly getting in the way. By all reports, Sands of Time‚Äòs remake went through multiple iterations, scrapped and started over at least twice, and eventually was the victim of so much feature-creep that it was adding all-new powers, making Farah an entirely different character (for the better, I should add, but in the most complex way), and adding all-new content.

However, in the hands of a super-capable and proven AA team with a proclivity for the genre and a love of the original, it could have been a far more straightforward process. That 2003 original doesn‚Äôt need new powers, nor new levels, because it was fantastically good. It‚Äôs one of the best third-person action games ever made, and featured a time-manipulation gimmick that should have become industry standard. At 23 years old, the original is still a great game, but a clunky and dated one that would benefit so wonderfully from a modern refresh. And that‚Äôs all anyone had ever been hoping for from Ubisoft.

I‚Äôm sure there are many throwing up their arms and claiming that I‚Äôm over-simplifying things here. And yes, I‚Äôm being perfunctory, but I‚Äôd argue that‚Äôs because this is all relative. You might be surprised to learn just how needlessly complicated Ubisoft has made making games, even as far back as the 2000s. . I remember visiting Ubisoft Montreal for the announcement of Splinter Cell: Double Agent in 2005, and sitting in their offices as executives explained that development of the game was taking place 24 hours a day by being spread across at least three international studios. When Montreal finished work, they tagged in Ubisoft Milan, who would then pass the baton to Ubisoft Shanghai, and then back to Montreal. There were multiple daily video calls (2005 video calls at that) to try to manage this. Throughout the creation of the game it was also worked on by Ubisoft Toronto, Paris-based Gameloft, and North Carolina‚Äôs Red Storm. Imagine working like that. Try to imagine a more chaotic way to develop a game. (I remember asking developers how it could possibly work, and the rather taut smiles as they explained that it ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt easy.‚Äù)

Something > Nothing

So no, a AA team making a $50 million (or even a $5 million) game won‚Äôt deliver the spectacle and mainstream breakthrough appeal of Battlefield, but nor does it need to. If you‚Äôre spending $400m on a game (before you even factor in the cost of a global promotional campaign and wildly expensive influencer events), you need it to be bringing in numbers as close to a billion dollars as possible. If that‚Äôs not at all realistic, then the project can‚Äôt get greenlit in the first place. But if you‚Äôve spent $50m, and justifiably charge $60 for a top-quality product, you are in the black with so many fewer sales. If your game hits (and let‚Äôs remember, we‚Äôre in this mess because of all the $200m+ gambles that have missed), you could be in for vast profits.

And it‚Äôs not fantasy figures, either! Arc Raiders announced this month that it has sold 12 million copies, which at $40 a pop amounts to $480,000,000. Yup. Half a billion bucks. Sure, minus store fees that‚Äôs ‚Äúonly‚Äù $336 million. We don‚Äôt know its development costs, but developers have stated it was nowhere near AAA budgets. And this is a game with optional in-game cosmetic purchases, meaning that figure is going to be so much higher.

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33‚Äôs developers claim it cost less than $10 million to make, and it had sold over 6 million copies by the end of 2025. That means the $50 game has brought in at least $300,000,000 before store tithes. That‚Äôs a 3000 percent profit, and these are the numbers from before the game won all the 2025 GOTY awards and the sales that will have resulted from that.

These are certainly stand-out examples from last year (although only some of them), but these are figures Ubisoft or EA would sell their grandchildren‚Äôs souls to see. The point is, I‚Äôm not talking out of my hat here about the potential of spending far less on a far smaller team.

Many AA teams wouldn‚Äôt be interested in making a licensed game using someone else‚Äôs IP, and honestly, I wouldn‚Äôt want to trust a big-name publisher right now even if I were one who did. But many would! If you‚Äôre a small team with a $10 million project that didn‚Äôt catch fire, you‚Äôre in a very difficult place no matter how incredibly talented you might be. Many, many mid-size studios fold at that point, but what if there was the route of being trusted with the next Dead Space, or Legacy of Kain, or Sleeping Dogs, or Thief, or Trespasser, or Command & Conquer, or Titanfall, or Splinter Cell, or SSX, or Red Faction, or‚Ä¶

Maybe there‚Äôs some big, fatal flaw with this concept that would come to the surface on trying. But I‚Äôm really doubtful. The issue is the complete lack of ever trying! And honestly, in their crumbling, fire-sale-driven state, what does an Ubisoft or an EA have to lose?! There hasn‚Äôt been a Splinter Cell game since 2013, meaning for the last 13 years precisely $0 has been made on new Splinter Cell games. I realize that‚Äôs perhaps somewhat obvious, but it‚Äôs a really rather important point! A $10,000,000 Splinter Cell that ‚Äúonly‚Äù sells a million copies at $50 a pop: that‚Äôs a 500 percent profit. And even if it might seem like small change in a world where (very, very few) games bring in a billion dollars, it‚Äôs a heck of a lot more than $0.

item.title: Palworld Studio Has Devs Share Screenshots Of Steam Playtime To Prove They‚Äôre ‚ÄòTrue‚Äô Gamers
item.content:encoded:
Do you want to work on Palworld? Do you have an embarrassingly long Steam history to prove it? Will BioWare use a similar test to hire its new production director for Mass Effect 5? And can the next Monster Hunter Wilds patch finally fix performance on PC? It‚Äôs the latest edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily roundup of gaming news, rumors, and culture. This is my new favorite behind the scenes game tease. Game companies should spend less time firing people and more time being silly.

Gamers without Steam achievements need not apply

What makes a good game designer? For Palworld maker Pocketpair it‚Äôs people who play a lot of Steam games and can explain why their favorite ones are good. Don‚Äôt have a Steam game history? Don‚Äôt even bother applying. CEO Takuro Mizobe says people have to submit screenshots of their playtime and those without any are screened out.

‚ÄúIn the interview, we ask them to explain the game mechanics of the titles that rank high in their Steam playtime, why they think those specific mechanics were adopted, and what makes that title stand out when compared to other games in the same genre,‚Äù Mizobe wrote on X (via Automaton). ‚ÄúPocketpair is recruiting game creators who are true Steam gamers!‚Äù

Monster Hunter Wilds‚Äò next big performance patch arrives next week

‚ÄúThis patch will include optimization improvements for Steam-specific processes and options to reduce processing load,‚Äù reads an announcement on the server status account for an outage starting January 27. ‚ÄúIt will also include a review of presets.‚Äù Another update will follow quickly after on February 18. Fans are hoping this is the one that finally makes a big difference with how the game runs on PC, especially after one modder apparently discovered a weird DLC check bug that was killing framerates.

BioWare is hiring for Mass Effect 5

‚ÄúWe are looking for a Production Director with a passion for the Mass Effect universe to serve as a high-impact leader on our next Mass Effect title,‚Äù reads a new job posting. ‚ÄúYou will partner closely with creative leadership, studio teams, and internal and external partners to champion the game‚Äôs vision and ensure its execution at the highest quality bar.‚Äù That person will report directly to project lead Michael Gamble. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gonna be awesome,‚Äù he wrote on X.

Vampire Crawlers will have a free demo next month

The Vampire Survivors-turned-3D-deckbuilder dungeon crawler spin-off will be free-to-try starting on February 23 on Steam and Xbox Game Pass. The 3D pixel-art genre mash-up has been looking very neat and has a new trailer explaining more of how its gameplay will work.

Epic has a secret $800 million deal with Google

‚ÄúEpic‚Äôs technology is used by many companies in the space Google is operating in to train their products, so the ability for Google to use the Unreal Engine more fulsome‚Ä¶sorry, I‚Äôm blowing this confidentiality,‚Äù CEO Tim Sweeney told a court questioning its settlement with the search giant, The Verge reports. The deal, which is for Epic buying Google‚Äôs services, is apparently related to ‚Äúthe metaverse‚Äù and will include both companies marketing one another‚Äôs products. It‚Äôs definitely not part of some sweetheart arrangement of the kind that Sweeney previously railed against.

  • Ubisoft‚Äôs stock is on life support 
  • Fans can‚Äôt figure out why one of the Yakuza 3 remake‚Äôs back alleys is so ugly
  • Remedy defends Tim Sweeney‚Äôs honor over Alan Wake 2 not being on Steam

item.title: Anker Offloads Its USB-C Car Charger (167.5W Max, 3-Port) at Its Lowest Price After Power Bank Deals
item.content:encoded:
The Anker iPhone 17 USB-C Car Charger is a compact three-port car charger that charges your phone, tablet, and laptop from a single 12V outlet. This charger features an ultra-compact metal case that fits neatly in the socket without obstructing other controls. Two USB-C ports and one USB-A port share a combined high-output port, so you can charge multiple devices at once. By allowing this design to be less cluttered and replacing multiple bulkier adapters with a single compact, unobtrusive charger that sits in a corner, it will make your vehicle look better.

You can find the Anker iPhone 17 USB-C Car Charger on Amazon today for only $34, which is a $20 discount and 37% off the original retail price of $54.

See at Amazon

A quick and easy way to charge your iPhone in the car

This charger has three outputs, depending on the type of device you‚Äôre connecting. There is a first USB-C port that can supply up to 100 watts of power to compatible laptops and larger tablets. The second USB-C port will provide up to 45 watts of power for charging most phones, smaller tablets, and mid-sized devices. The third port is a USB-A port that supplies up to 22.5 watts of power for charging older cables and accessories such as battery packs and wireless earbud cases. All three ports are designed to work together to split the available power among the various devices, ensuring they all receive enough voltage to continue functioning.

To keep the Anker iPhone 17 USB-C Car Charger compact, convenient, and easy to use in the vehicle, some design decisions were made to ensure it fits well in the car outlet. The unit‚Äôs housing is a short, cylindrical shape designed to fit lower in the outlet than most chargers, minimizing the chance of accidentally bumping the unit when reaching for controls. The contact points on the unit are reinforced to maintain a solid connection with the 12V outlet and withstand repeated insertion and removal from the outlet, as well as vibrations and movement between vehicles. Additionally, the unit has built-in protection against overvoltage, overcurrent, and overheating when using the higher-wattage options to charge multiple devices simultaneously.

Inside the packaging, you‚Äôll find the Anker iPhone 17 USB-C Car Charger, a 3.3-foot USB-C-to-USB-C charging cable, a user manual, and an 18-month manufacturer warranty for the hardware. The included cable lets you start charging a USB-C phone or tablet right away, without having to search for another charging cable, and the warranty provides additional peace of mind, knowing the charger will be protected should it see extensive use. When considering compact size, protection features, and the wide range of compatible devices, along with the discounted price of $34, down from the regular retail price of $54, the Anker iPhone 17 USB-C Car Charger provides a significant amount of charging capacity for an affordable price.
